page.text: 181 BALLARDVALE STREET, SUITE 202, WILMINGTON, MA 01887 TELEPHONE: (978) 570-2999 FACSIMILE: (978) 658-3044
Ms. Heather L. Monticup, P.E., Project Manager
Ms. Susannah E. Barnes, E.I.T., Engineer
2299 Lafayette Road (US Route 1) – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
Greenman-Pedersen, Inc. (GPI) has prepared this Traffic Impact and Access Study (TIAS) for a
proposed Taco Bell restaurant to be located at 2299 Lafayette Road (US Route 1) in Portsmouth,
New Hampshire. The existing site is currently vacant. The project consists of constructing a
2,500 square foot Taco Bell restaurant with drive-through window and 50 seats on the site.
Access to the site is currently provided by an existing driveway on Lafayette Road which also
provides access to the Advance Auto Parts. As part of the development, access to the site will
remain the same. Since Lafayette Road is a state-maintained highway, the project will require a
state-issued Driveway Permit. Accordingly, a Traffic Study Outline was prepared and submitted
to the New Hampshire Department of Transportation (NHDOT) on December 17, 2014. It was
determined that no Scoping Meeting was required. A copy of the email and Outline is provided
in the Appendix. This study has been prepared in conformance with the Outline and current
NHDOT guidelines for traffic impact assessment. Figure 1 shows the site in relation to the
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
Evaluation of the traffic impacts associated with the proposed Project requires an assessment of
existing and projected traffic volumes on the adjacent streets, the volume of traffic expected to
be generated by the Project, and the impact this traffic will have on the adjacent streets and
intersections. In preparing this study for the proposed site development, the following
Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Advance Auto Parts Driveway
Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Springbrook Circle and Southgate Plaza Driveway
A description of the geometric characteristics of the intersections is provided below.
Within the study area, Lafayette Road is an urban principal arterial roadway in the north-south
direction. The posted speed limit is 35 miles per hour (mph) in each direction with land uses
within the study area consisting of commercial uses. Adjacent to the site, Lafayette Road
provides two general purpose lanes in the southbound direction, and one general purpose lane in
the northbound direction, with a two-way left-turn lane (TWLTL). The TWLTL becomes an
exclusive left-turn lane just south of the site at the intersection of Lafayette Road at Springbrook

text.b: Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Advance Auto Parts Driveway

page.text: The Advanced Auto Parts driveway meets Lafayette Road to form an unsignalized T-type
intersection. Directional travel along Lafayette Road is separated by a TWLTL. The Advanced
Auto Parts driveway approach provides no pavement markings, however, the driveway is wide
enough to accommodate two lanes of exiting traffic and is used an exclusive left-turn lane and an

text.b: Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Springbrook Circle and Southgate Plaza Driveway

page.text: The Southgate Plaza driveway and Springbrook Circle meet Lafayette Road from the west and
east, respectively, to form a four-way intersection under actuated coordinated traffic signal
control. The Lafayette Road northbound approach consists of an exclusive left-turn lane and one
shared through/right-turn lane. The Lafayette Road southbound approach consists of an
exclusive left-turn lane, one through lane, and one shared through/right- turn lane. Directional
travel along Lafayette Road is separated by a double yellow centerline at the intersection. The
Springbrook Circle westbound approach consists of a shared left-turn/through lane and a right-
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
turn lane with no pavement markings designating the lanes. Directional travel along
Springbrook Circle is separated by a raised median island at the intersection. The Southgate
Plaza driveway eastbound approach consists of a shared left-turn/through lane and an exclusive
right-turn lane. Directional travel at the Southgate Plaza driveway is separated by a raised
Base traffic conditions within the study area were developed by conducting manual turning
movement counts (TMCs), vehicle classification counts, and automatic traffic recorder (ATR)
TMCs and vehicle classification counts were performed
during the weekday PM peak period (4:00 PM to 6:00 PM) and the Saturday midday peak period
(11:00 AM to 2:00 PM). These peak periods were chosen based on the hours of operation of the
proposed use and to be consistent with NHDOT traffic study guidelines. The ATRs were used to
obtain weekday daily traffic volumes on Lafayette Road adjacent to the site.
reoccurrence of snowfall events, the Saturday daily volumes could not be obtained at the time the
study was prepared. Therefore, Saturday daily traffic volumes will be obtained as soon as
weather permits and the information will be submitted to the City of Portsmouth and the
NHDOT. All traffic count data are provided in the Appendix.
Traffic on a given roadway typically fluctuates throughout the year depending on the area and
the type of roadway. Based on NHDOT guidelines for the preparation of a traffic study, existing
traffic volumes must represent the peak of the monthly average peak-hour conditions. To
determine if the data needed to be adjusted to account for this fluctuation, seasonal adjustment
and historical count data provided by NHDOT were reviewed.
the January weekday traffic volumes are 27.1 percent lower than peak-month conditions and the
February Saturday traffic volumes are 21.9 percent lower than peak-month conditions.
Additionally, this information indicated that the January traffic volumes are 22.4 percent lower
than the peak-month volumes during weekday PM peak period and February traffic volumes are
12.2 percent lower than the peak-month conditions during the Saturday midday peak period.
Therefore, the January and February traffic counts were upwardly adjusted to reflect peak-month
conditions. The NHDOT seasonal adjustment factors are provided in the Appendix.
Table 1 summarizes the existing adjusted traffic volumes on Lafayette Road adjacent to the site.

prepared. Therefore, when the local data is received, it will be reviewed and compared to the

Vehicle speed measurements were obtained along Lafayette Road adjacent to the site by
measuring the elapsed time for vehicles traveling a short, pre-measured distance between two
checkpoints. The travel time was recorded using ATRs and the speed was derived by dividing
the elapsed time into the measured distance between checkpoints. The primary use of this
information is explained in detail within the Sight Distance section of this TIAS. Essentially, the
speeds are correlated to sight distance measurements taken at the location of the site driveway to
assure that adequate sight distances exist at the driveway to provide safe operation. The results
of the speed measurements are summarized in Table 3.
Average speed of all observed vehicles.
Speed at or below which 85 percent of all observed vehicles travel.

The average speeds on Lafayette Road are generally consistent with the posted speed limit of
The Cooperative Alliance for Seacoast Transportation (COAST) provides public transportation
for the Seacoast region of New Hampshire (Rockingham and Strafford Counties) and Berwick,
Maine. In Portsmouth, the COAST Route 41 Lafayette Road Trolley INBOUND provides a bus
stop location directly adjacent to the project site on Lafayette Road. This bus stop is labeled as
Lafayette Road/Springbrook Circle (Advanced Auto Parts). Route 41 provides connection from
Lafayette Road (Hillcrest Estates) to Market Square. In addition, Route 41 connects to Routes 2,
4, and 40. Route 41 operates Monday through Friday, approximately once or twice per hour
between 3:07 PM and 9:02 PM and Saturday, approximately once every two to three hours
between 7:37 AM and 9:00 PM. The weekday and Saturday schedules for Route 41 (Lafayette
Road Trolley) are provided in the Appendix.
To estimate the impact of site-generated traffic within the study area, existing traffic volumes
were projected to the expected opening year (2016) of the Project and to the expected opening
year plus ten years (2026). These design horizons were chosen to be consistent with City of
Portsmouth and NHDOT guidelines for the preparation of a traffic study. Traffic volumes on the
roadway network at these times will include existing traffic, new traffic due to normal
background traffic growth, and traffic related to any significant development by others expected
to be completed within the area by the 2016 and 2026 design years. Consideration of these
factors resulted in the development of 2016 No-Build and 2026 No-Build traffic volumes, which
projects traffic without the proposed Project built. The incremental impacts of the proposed
project may then be determined by adding site-generated traffic volumes (Build conditions) and
making comparisons to the No-Build conditions.
To develop the 2016 No-Build and 2026 No-Build forecast volumes, two components of traffic
growth were considered. First, an annual growth percentage was determined based on the
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
historical traffic count data obtained from NHDOT
. The historical traffic count data indicate
that traffic volumes in the area have been decreasing at a rate of 1.13 percent since 2007.
order to provide a conservative (worse-case) analysis scenario, a compounded annual traffic
growth rate of 1.0 percent per year was assumed to account for general population growth and
the traffic generated by smaller area developments. The NHDOT historical traffic volume data
Second, any traffic that may be generated by planned developments that may add a substantial
volume of traffic through the study area during the design horizons was considered. Based on
discussions with the Transportation Planner for the City of Portsmouth, two other developments
are currently planned in the area. The Southgate Plaza is currently 80-85% occupied, and
therefore, traffic associated with the vacant space in the Plaza has been added to the No-Build
traffic networks. In addition, two two-story medical office buildings with 20,000 square feet of
gross floor area in each building are to be located at 1900 Lafayette Road. The trip-generation
developed from the Traffic Impact Assessment
has been added to the No-Build traffic networks.
The background development data can be found in the Appendix.
Based on discussions with the NHDOT, the traffic signal timings along this corridor of Lafayette
Road will be optimized under a Portsmouth Congestion Mitigation and Air Quality (CMAQ)
project which is anticipated to occur later this year. Therefore, the future signal timings have
been optimized within the future condition analyses.
Based on discussions with the Public Works department of the City of Portsmouth, there is an
NHDOT project in the planning stages that includes improvements from Constitution Avenue to
Wilson Road and from Ocean Road to White Cedar Boulevard. However, this improvement
project is on hold due to an easement issue and has an advertise date of October 4, 2021.
Accordingly, these improvements are not included within the future conditions.

The 2016 No-Build peak-hour traffic volumes were developed by applying a 1.0 percent
compounded annual traffic growth rate (1.0 percent compounded over one year) to the
2015 Existing traffic volumes and adding traffic to be generated by the vacant space within the
Southgate Plaza and the two medical office buildings. The 2026 No-Build peak hour traffic
volumes were developed by applying a total growth of 11.6 percent (1.0 percent compounded
over eleven years) to the 2015 Existing traffic volumes and adding traffic to be generated by the
vacant space within the Southgate Plaza and the two medical office buildings. The 2016 and
2026 No-Build peak-hour traffic volumes are shown graphically on Figures 3 and 4 for the
weekday PM and Saturday midday peak hours.
As proposed, the development consists of constructing a ±2,500 square foot fast-food restaurant
with a drive-through window. Traffic to be generated by the Project was forecast using the trip
rates contained in the latest edition of the
for Land Use Code 934 (Fast-Food Restaurant with Drive-Through
. Table 4 summarizes the results of the trip generation estimates. All trip generation
data are provided in the Appendix.
It should be noted that not all of the vehicle trips expected to be generated by the proposed
Project represent new trips on the study area roadway system. Studies have shown that for
developments such as the one proposed, a substantial portion of the site-generated vehicle trips
are already present in the adjacent passing stream of traffic or are diverted from another route to
the proposed site. Based on data presented in the ITE Trip Generation Handbook, the average
pass-by trip percentage of vehicular trips generated for ITE Land Use Code 934 (Fast-Food
Restaurant with Drive-Through Window) is 49 percent during the weekday AM peak hour and
50 percent during the weekday PM peak hour
. There is no information available for the
Saturday midday peak hour, therefore, a 49 percent pass-by trip percentage will be used which
represents the lower percentage of pass-by between the weekday AM and weekday PM peak
hours to represent a more conservative (worse-case) analysis. Table 4 summarizes the results of
the trip generation estimates. The pass-by data are provided in the Appendix.
Edition; Institute of Transportation Engineers; Washington, DC; 2012.

As shown in Table 4, the proposed restaurant development is expected to generate 42 new
vehicle trips (23 entering and 19 exiting) during the weekday PM peak hour and 76 new vehicle
trips (39 entering and 37 exiting) during the Saturday midday peak hour. It should be noted that
the volume of pass-by traffic does not reduce the total volume of traffic generated by the
development and the external trips will still be realized as turning movements at the site
Having estimated project-generated vehicle trips, the next step is to determine the distribution of
project traffic and assign these trips to the local roadway network. The directional distribution of
site traffic is dependent on expected travel routes to and from the site and existing travel patterns.
Accordingly, approximately 50 percent of the site-generated traffic is expected to travel to and
from the north along Lafayette Road and 50 percent is expected to and from the south on

Access to the site is currently provided by an existing driveway on Lafayette Road which also
provides access to the Advance Auto Parts. As part of the development, access to the site will
To identify potential safety concerns associated with site access and egress,
sight distances have been evaluated at the intersection of the site driveway with Lafayette Road
to determine if the available sight distances for vehicles exiting the site meet or exceed the
minimum distances required for approaching vehicles to safely observe. The available sight
distances were compared with minimum requirements, as established by the American
Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials (AASHTO)
the national standard by which vehicle sight distance is calculated, measured, and reported. In
addition, the available sight distances were compared with the NHDOT’s requirement of 400 feet
Sight distance is the length of roadway ahead that is visible to the driver. Stopping Sight
Distance (SSD) is the minimum distance required for a vehicle traveling at a certain speed to
safely observe and stop a stationary object in its path before reaching it. The values are based on
a driver perception and reaction time of 2.5 seconds and a braking distance calculated for wet,
level pavements. When the roadway is either on an upgrade or downgrade, grade correction
factors are applied. SSD is measured from an eye height of 3.5 feet to an object height of 2 feet
above street level, equivalent to the taillight height of a passenger car. The SSD is measured
along the centerline of the traveled way of the major roadway.
Intersection sight distance (ISD) is provided on minor street approaches to allow the drivers of
stopped vehicles a sufficient view of the major roadway to decide when to enter the major
roadway. By definition, ISD is the minimum distance required for a motorist exiting a minor
street to turn onto the major street, without being overtaken by an approaching vehicle reducing
its speed from the design speed to 70 percent of the design speed. The ISD is measured from an
eye height of 3.5 feet to an object height of 3.5 feet above street level. The use of an object
height equal to the driver eye height makes ISDs reciprocal (i.e., if one driver can see another
vehicle, then the driver of that vehicle can also see the first vehicle). When the minor street is on
an upgrade that exceeds 3 percent, grade correction factors are applied. The ISD design values
for right turns from a minor street are less than the design values for left turns because, in
making right turns, drivers generally accept gaps that are slightly shorter than those accepted in
The SSD is generally more important as it represents the minimum distance required for safe
stopping while ISD is based only upon acceptable speed reductions to the approaching traffic
A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets; American Association of State Highway and
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
stream. The ISD, however, must be equal to or greater than the minimum required SSD in order
to provide safe operations at the intersection. In accordance with the AASHTO manual, “If the

text.i: available sight distance for an entering or crossing vehicle is at least equal to the appropriate
stopping sight distance for the major road, then drivers have sufficient sight distance to
anticipate and avoid collisions. However, in some cases, this may require a major-road vehicle
to stop or slow to accommodate the maneuver by a minor-road vehicle. To enhance traffic
operations, intersection sight distances that exceed stopping sight distances are desirable along

page.text: the major road.” Accordingly, ISD should be at least equal to the distance required to allow a
driver approaching the minor road to safely stop.
The available SSD and ISD at the proposed site driveway were measured in the field and
compared to minimum requirements as established by AASHTO. Since the distance required to
stop a vehicle is dependent on the speed of that vehicle, speed studies were conducted as
presented in the Existing Conditions: Vehicle Speeds section. Based on both the posted speed
limit and the observed speeds, the SSD and ISD requirements at the site driveway intersection
with Lafayette Road were calculated. The required minimum sight distances for each direction
are compared to the available distances, as shown in Table 5.
Values based on AASHTO requirements for 85
percentile speeds of 42 mph for Lafayette Road northbound travel and 44 mph
Values based on AASHTO requirements for SSD.
Values based on AASHTO requirements for posted speed limit of 35 mph on Lafayette Road.
As indicated in Table 5, available sight distances at the proposed Lafayette Road site driveway
exceed the minimum and desirable SSD and ISD requirements for safe operation. The available
sight lines also exceed the NHDOT requirement of 400 feet of All-Season Safe Sight Distance.
To ensure the safe and efficient flow of traffic to and from the site, it is recommended that any
proposed plantings, vegetation, landscaping, and signing along the site frontage be kept low to
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
the ground (no more than 3.0 feet above street level) or set back sufficiently from the edge of
Lafayette Road and the proposed site driveway so as not to inhibit the available sight lines.
The proposed drive-through facility has been designed to separate drive-through traffic from
other site circulating traffic, not to impede or impair access into or out of parking spaces, not to
impede or impair vehicle or pedestrian traffic movements, and located to minimize conflicts
between pedestrian and vehicular traffic. Both the entrance and exit for the drive-through
facility will not enter or exit directly into the public right-of-way.
Based on an article published in the ITE Journal, fast-food restaurants typically experience, on
average, a 7 vehicle maximum queue at the drive-through window.
hamburger restaurants and donut shops. Taco Bell restaurant drive-through queues, however, are
typically much less than those found for chain hamburger fast-food restaurants or donut shops.
Therefore, these data suggest that the maximum back of queue for the proposed restaurant is
expected to be 7 vehicles or less. In addition, Taco Bell of America, Inc. typically designs all of
their facilities to accommodate an 8 vehicle drive-through queue, assuming 18 to 20 feet in
length per vehicle. Therefore, the proposed stacking capacity of 8 vehicles should be sufficient
Consistent with the City of Portsmouth Site Plan Review Regulations stacking space size of
10 feet by 20 feet, the proposed 12-foot wide drive-through lane can accommodate 8 vehicles
within the striped drive-through lane assuming 20 feet per vehicle (160 feet). Based on queuing
data provided by ITE and observations conducted at other Taco Bell facilities, the proposed
drive-through window lane is anticipated to accommodate the expected vehicle queues on site
without disrupting on-site circulation or traffic flow along Lafayette Road. A 12-foot by-pass
lane is provided in order to permit vehicles to exit the site without using the drive-through lane.
Based on the trip generation and distribution estimates for this project, the traffic volumes
associated with the proposed Project were assigned to the roadway network. The site-generated
traffic networks are shown on Figure 5 for the weekday PM and Saturday midday peak hours.
The site-generated traffic volumes were then added to the No-Build traffic volumes to develop
the Build peak hour traffic volume networks. The 2016 and 2026 Build peak hour traffic volume
networks are graphically depicted on Figures 6 and 7.
Queuing Areas for Drive-Thru Facilities; ITE Journal; May 1995.
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
A 5-foot wide sidewalk is proposed along the site frontage to provide connection from the
pedestrian accommodations at the intersection of Lafayette Road at Springbrook Circle and
Southgate Plaza to the COAST bus stop located adjacent to the proposed site. The sidewalk will
provide a safe refuge for pedestrians to wait for the bus.
The proposed Project will result in increases in traffic on the roadways leading to the site beyond
the study area. As shown on Figure 5, peak hour traffic volume increases ranging from 20 to
39 vehicles per hour are expected with the construction of the Project. These increases represent,
on average, approximately one additional vehicle every 1.5 to 3 minutes during the peak hours.
Level of service (LOS) analyses were conducted at the study area intersections under
2015 Existing, 2016 No-Build, 2016 Build, 2026 No-Build, and 2026 Build conditions during
the weekday PM and Saturday midday peak hours. The capacity and queue analyses
methodology is based on the concepts and procedures in the Highway Capacity Manual (HCM)
and is described in the Appendix.
The queue analysis methodology for signalized and unsignalized intersections is based on the
concepts and procedures described in the HCM. The maximum back of queue (measured in feet)
percentile signal cycle was calculated for each critical lane group during the peak
periods studied. The back of queue is the length of a backup of vehicles from the stop line of a
signalized intersection to the last vehicle in the queue that is required to stop, regardless of the
signal indication. The length of this queue depends on a number of factors including signal
timing, vehicle arrival patterns, and the saturation flow rate.
The results of the level of service and queue analyses are shown in Table 6 (2016 design year
conditions) and Table 7 (2026 design year conditions) and are discussed below. Capacity and
8Highway Capacity Manual 2000; Transportation Research Board; Washington, D.C.; 2000.
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
queue analyses were conducted at the study area intersections utilizing Synchro 8 software and
the default values within the program.
Due to the fact that the Advanced Auto Parts driveway and proposed site driveway does not have
pavement markings, it was analyzed in all conditions as it operates, having a left-turn lane and a
In addition, it is expected that motorists typically accept smaller gaps in traffic at unsignalized
intersections during peak periods of traffic than reflected in the analysis model and, therefore, do
not wait as long to exit into the main line of traffic as shown in the analysis results. Therefore,
unsignalized intersection operating results may be better than as presented in this memorandum.
All analyses worksheets are provided in the Appendix.

text.b: Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Advanced Auto Parts Driveway/Proposed Site Driveway

page.text: As shown in Tables 6 and 7, under existing and future traffic volume conditions, at the
unsignalized intersection of Lafayette Road at Advanced Auto Parts driveway and the proposed
site driveway all movements on Lafayette Road are expected to operate at acceptable levels
(LOS B or better). The site driveway currently operates at LOS D. As a result of background
and historical growth, the site driveway is anticipated to operate at LOS D and LOS E under
2016 conditions and LOS E and LOS F under 2026 conditions for the weekday PM and Saturday
midday peak hours, respectively. Finally, as a result of the proposed development the site
driveway is anticipated to drop from LOS E to LOS F during the 2026 conditions in the weekday
PM peak hour, due to a ±12 second increase in delay.

text.b: Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Springbrook Circle and Southgate Plaza Driveway

page.text: Under existing and future traffic volume conditions, the signalized intersection of Lafayette
Road at Springbrook Circle and the Southgate Plaza driveway is expected to operate at an overall
LOS C after the proposed development is in place. There are no drops in LOS as a result of the
proposed Taco Bell restaurant. Increases in delay as a result of the proposed development are
less than 8 seconds with increases in queue lengths of 2 vehicles or less on any movement.
addition, all v/c ratios are anticipated to be below 1.00 (0.95 or less), indicating there will be
adequate capacity to accommodate the anticipated traffic volumes.

Existing and future conditions in the study area have been described, analyzed, and evaluated
with respect to traffic operations and the impact of the proposed Taco Bell restaurant
development. Conclusions of this effort and recommendations are presented below.
As proposed, the project consists of constructing a 2,500 square foot Taco Bell restaurant
with drive-through window and 50 seats on the site. Access to the site is currently provided
by an existing driveway on Lafayette Road which also provides access to the Advance Auto
Parts. As part of the development, access to the site will remain the same.
Collision data for the study area intersections were obtained from NHDOT for the most
recent complete three-year period (2011 through 2013). Based on the NHDOT collision data
from 2011 through 2013, there were two collisions at the intersection of Lafayette Road at
Springbrook Circle and the Southgate Plaza driveway. Both collisions resulted in personal
injury and occurred during the weekday AM commuter peak period.
proposed restaurant development is expected to generate 42 new vehicle trips
(23 entering and 19 exiting) during the weekday PM peak hour and 76 new vehicle trips
(39 entering and 37 exiting) during the Saturday midday peak hour. Increases in traffic on
roadways beyond the study area as a result of the Project during the weekday PM and
Saturday midday peak hours are expected in the range of 20 to 39 vehicles per hour. These
increases represent, on average, approximately one additional vehicle every 1.5 to 3 minutes
Available sight distances at the proposed Lafayette Road site driveway exceed the minimum
and desirable SSD and ISD requirements for safe operation. The available sight lines also
exceed the NHDOT requirement of 400 feet of All-Season Safe Sight Distance. To ensure
the safe and efficient flow of traffic to and from the site, it is recommended that any proposed
plantings, vegetation, landscaping, and signing along the site frontage be kept low to the
ground (no more than 3.0 feet above street level) or set back sufficiently from the edge of
Lafayette Road and the proposed site driveway so as not to inhibit the available sight lines.
Consistent with the City of Portsmouth Site Plan Review Regulations stacking space size of
10 feet by 20 feet, the proposed 12-foot wide drive-through lane can accommodate 8 vehicles
within the striped drive-through lane assuming 20 feet per vehicle (160 feet). Based on
queuing data provided by ITE and observations conducted at other Taco Bell facilities, the
proposed drive-through window lane is anticipated to accommodate the expected vehicle
queues on site without disrupting on-site circulation or traffic flow along Lafayette Road. A
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
12-foot by-pass lane is provided in order to permit vehicles to exit the site without using the
A 5-foot wide sidewalk is proposed along the site frontage to provide connection from the
pedestrian accommodations at the intersection of Lafayette Road at Springbrook Circle and
Southgate Plaza to the COAST bus stop located adjacent to the proposed site. The sidewalk
will provide a safe refuge for pedestrians to wait for the bus.
Under existing and future traffic volume conditions, at the unsignalized intersection of
Lafayette Road at Advanced Auto Parts driveway and the proposed site driveway all
movements on Lafayette Road are expected to operate at acceptable levels (LOS B or better).
The site driveway currently operates at LOS D. As a result of background and historical
growth, the site driveway is anticipated to operate at LOS D and LOS E under 2016
conditions and LOS E and LOS F under 2026 conditions for the weekday PM and Saturday
midday peak hours, respectively. Finally, as a result of the proposed development the site
driveway is anticipated to drop from LOS E to LOS F during the 2026 conditions in the
weekday PM peak hour, due to a ±12 second increase in delay.
As a result of the proposed development project, the 95
expected to increase from approximately one vehicle to four-five vehicles in the worst-case

text.i: percentile queue is defined to be the queue length (in vehicles)
that has only a 5-percent probability of being exceeded during the analysis time period…it is
not typical of what an average driver would experience.”

page.text: accommodated on site without backing up into the pick-up window. In addition, the volume-
to-capacity (v/c) ratios are anticipated to be below 1.00 (0.71 or less), indicating there will be
adequate capacity to accommodate the anticipated traffic volumes.
Under existing and future traffic volume conditions, the signalized intersection of Lafayette
Road at Springbrook Circle and the Southgate Plaza driveway is expected to operate at an
overall LOS C after the proposed development is in place. There are no drops in LOS as a
result of the proposed Taco Bell restaurant. Increases in delay as a result of the proposed
development are less than 8 seconds with increases in queue lengths of 2 vehicles or less on
In addition, all v/c ratios are anticipated to be below 1.00 (0.95 or less),
indicating there will be adequate capacity to accommodate the anticipated traffic volumes.

I had a chance to look at this quickly and this should be a straight forward application as
This shared driveway was approved in 2005 ( see attached)

There is a center turn lane in front of the property now.
Therefore no scoping meeting is needed.

Subject: Portsmouth, NH - 2299 Lafayette Road - Taco Bell
We are working on a new Taco Bell project to be located at 2299 Lafayette Road (US Route 1) in Portsmouth,
NH. Attached for your information is the Preliminary Site Plan and a Traffic Study Outline which includes a Site Location
Map. We are sending this information to determine if a NHDOT Scoping Meeting will be required for the project. Please
let me know if you have any questions or need anything else.
This communication and any attachments are intended only for the use of the individual or entity named as the
addressee. It may contain information which is privileged and/or confidential under applicable law. If you are
not the intended recipient or such recipient's employee or agent, you are hereby notified that any dissemination,
copy or disclosure of this communication is strictly prohibited and to notify the sender immediately.
Taco Bell Restaurant – Portsmouth, New Hampshire
The following data will be collected and used in the preparation of a Traffic Impact and Access Study
for the proposed restaurant development to be located at 2299 Lafayette Road (US Route 1) in
The existing site is currently vacant. Based on our understanding of
the project, the project consists of constructing a 2,500 square foot Taco Bell restaurant with drive-
through window and 50 seats on the site. Access to the site is currently provided by an existing
driveway on Lafayette Road which also provides access to the Advance Auto Parts. As part of the
development, access to the site will remain the same. The Site Location Map is shown on Figure 1
Previous traffic counts were performed in August 2012 as part of the Southgate Plaza Expansion
. Manual turning movement counts (TMCs) and vehicle classification counts were conducted
at the following locations on Saturday, August 18, 2012, between 2:00 and 5:00 PM:
Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Springbrook Circle and Southgate Plaza Driveway
Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Constitution Avenue
Constitution Avenue at Southgate Plaza driveway and Friendly’s driveway
Constitution Avenue at Water Country driveway
In addition, TMCs and vehicle classification counts were conducted at the Constitution Avenue and
Water Country driveway unsignalized intersection on Saturday, August 25, 2012, between 4:00 and
Based on these data collection efforts, the peak hour was determined to occur between 2:15 and
3:15 PM at the Lafayette Road (US Route 1) signalized intersection with the Southgate Plaza
driveway and Springbrook Circle, and between 5:00 and 6:00 PM at the Constitution Avenue
unsignalized intersection with the Water Country driveway.
Traffic Evaluation Addendum Two, Proposed Southgate Plaza Expansion, Portsmouth, New Hampshire, August 2012; Stephen G.
1. TMCs and vehicle classification counts will be conducted during the weekday PM peak period
and during the Saturday midday peak period (11:00 AM to 2:00 PM),
unless otherwise decided by the NHDOT/City, at the following intersections:
Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Springbrook Circle and Southgate Plaza Driveway (S)
Lafayette Road (US Route 1) at Advanced Auto Parts Driveway (U)
If it is acceptable to the NHDOT and City of Portsmouth, the Saturday data from August 2012 could
be used and adjusted to 2015 conditions.
2. Automatic traffic recorder (ATR) counts will be conducted for 72 hours to collect both weekday
and Saturday daily traffic volumes along Lafayette Road (US Route 1) adjacent to the site.
3. Seasonal Adjustments: Since there are no peak-hour count stations in Portsmouth, the count
station in North Hampton on US Route 1, north of the B&M bridge will be used.
August is the peak month for weekday daily traffic volumes.
August is the peak month for weekday PM peak-hour traffic volumes.
July is the peak month for Saturday daily traffic volumes.
August is the peak month for Saturday midday peak-hour traffic volumes.
All new traffic counts will be collected in January; therefore, the following adjustments will be
January weekday daily traffic volumes would be upwardly adjusted by 27.1%.
January weekday PM peak-hour count data would be upwardly adjusted by 22.4%.
January Saturday daily traffic volumes would be upwardly adjusted by 29.0%.
January Saturday midday peak-hour count data would be adjusted upwardly by 11.9%.
4. Crash Data: Crash data will be obtained from the Portsmouth Police Department for the three
1. Historical Growth Rate: Historical ATR data were investigated along and off of US Route 1
nearby the study area from 5 daily counts stations.
Traffic in the area has decreased by 1.13% since 2007.
To provide a conservative (worse-case) analysis, a 1.0% compounded annual growth rate

text.b: or an annual growth rate acceptable to the NHDOT/City of Portsmouth

page.text: account for general population growth and the traffic generated by smaller area developments.
2. Background Developments: To be determined at the Scoping Meeting or through discussions with
3. Planned Roadway Improvements: To be determined at the Scoping Meeting or through
discussions with the City of Portsmouth.
1. Trip Generation: Traffic to be generated by the proposed development will be forecast using the
Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation Manual

text.b: (LUC) 934 (Fast-Food Restaurant with Drive-Through Window) based on gross floor area.

page.text: LUC 934 based on the number of seats was considered, yet resulted in lower anticipated vehicle
trips. Therefore, LUC 934 (Fast-Food Restaurant with Drive-Through Window) based on gross
floor area will be used in order to provide a more conservative approach.
2. Pass-By Trips: Pass-by trips were based on data provided in the ITE Trip Generation Handbook
for LUC 934 (Fast-Food Restaurant with Drive-Through Window).
Weekday AM Peak Hour: average pass-by rate is 49 %.
Weekday PM Peak Hour: average pass-by rate is 50 %.
Saturday Midday Peak Hour: no data is provided, therefore, an average pass-by rate of 49 %
will be used which represents the lower percentage of pass-by between the weekday AM and
weekday PM peak hours to represent a more conservative (worse-case) analysis.
Edition; Institute of Transportation Engineers; Washington, DC; 2012.
Edition; Institute of Transportation Engineers; Washington, DC; August 2014.
ITE LUC 934 (Fast-Food Restaurant with Drive-Through Window) for 2,500 sf.
50% of Total Trips during weekday PM peak hour and 49% of Total Trips during Saturday midday peak
Daily pass-by percentage information not available.
As shown in Table 1, the proposed restaurant development is expected to generate 42 new vehicle
trips (13 entering and 19 exiting) during the weekday PM peak hour and 76 new vehicle trips
(39 entering and 37 exiting) during the Saturday midday peak hour.
3. Trip Distribution: The distribution of proposed new site traffic on the area roadways will be based
on surrounding population densities, existing travel patterns, expected travel routes to the site, and
competing opportunities. The distribution of pass-by traffic will follow the directional distribution
of adjacent street traffic during the various peak hours observed on US Route 1 adjacent to the
Based on the August 2012 turning movement counts from the Southgate Plaza Expansion project,
the trip-distribution is expected to be 40 percent to/from the north on Lafayette Road
(US Route 1), 45 percent to/from the south on Lafayette Road (US Route 1), and 15 percent
to/from the west on Constitution Avenue.
